repository.label: Repository:

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research use. Audio-visual materials are not available in original format, and must be reformatted to a digital use copy.

userestrict.head: Ownership & Copyright
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94305-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/pubserv/permissions.html.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: [identification of item], J. Martin Evans Papers (SC1163). Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Martin Evans was born in Cardiff, Wales, on Feb. 2, 1935. After a two-year stint working in military intelligence for the Royal Air Force from 1953 to 1955, Evans attended Oxford, where he received his BA in 1958 from Jesus College, and his MA and DPhil from Merton College in 1963. At Oxford, his thesis advisor was Dame Helen Gardner, the doyenne of 17th-century studies. Under her guidance, he began a lifelong career in Milton studies. Gardner was influential in other ways: She convinced Evans to apply to Stanford when the academic job market in Britain was so poor that 250 scholars with doctorates in English were competing for two university positions.

Evans was offered the job, and immediately flew to Switzerland and proposed to Mariella Lafranchi, whom he had met at Oxford. He didn't know half her family had emigrated to California decades before; Evans moved into a large extended family in the United States and never looked back.
In 2004, the Milton Society of America named him as a prestigious "honored scholar" for lifetime achievement.

He hosted a 400th birthday party for John Milton in 2008, with a marathon reading of Paradise Lost – some called it a "Martinfest." The event reunited many of his former students from across the United States and Canada.

At his death, he was in his 50th year of teaching at Stanford. He held many awards for his teaching and service, including the Bing Award for teaching (1992), the Richard W. Lyman Award (1990) and the Dean's Award for Distinguished Teaching (1984). The 1987 Walter J. Gores Award for Excellence in Teaching cited "the magnificence of his teaching at all levels of the department curriculum" and "the passion about literature that infuses all his teaching and writing."

Evans was associate dean of the School of Humanities and Sciences (1977-81), director of undergraduate studies (1983-86) and chair of the English Department (1988-91). He was named the William R. Kenan Jr. Professor in 2002.

He was a champion of the humanities, and passionate in their defense: "The humanist's material is not a mysterious concatenation of natural phenomena or a mass of raw statistical data waiting to be given significance by the ordering mind of the analyst," he wrote in a 2009 article in Stanford magazine.

Evans was survived by his wife of almost 50 years, Mariella Evans of Stanford; his daughter Jessica Evans, his son-in-law Yung Duong and grandson, Owen Evans-Duong, all of Oakland; and his daughter Joanna Evans and son-in-law David Harris of Ojai, Calif.

did.unittitle: Introduction: Week 9 English 5 Lit-Politics - Quiet American

physdesc.extent: Contains draft, "Corridors of Power: The British Political System"
Contains draft, "Americans in Paris".

Contains "Keeping Faith with Desire" and "The politics of androgyny" by Barbara Charlesworth Gelpi; "Narcissus Interrupted: Specularity and the Subject of the Tudor State" and "Protestant Erotics: Idolatry and Interpretation in Spenser's Faerie Queene" by Linda Gregerson; publication, "The Worlds of Victorian Fiction"; "My Grande Naufrage: Fiction and Political Obsession", "Was Lia de Putti dead at 22?", "Notes on the rhetoric of anti-realist fiction", and "The Illuminating Distortion" by Albert J. Guerard.

Contains several publications by John Felstiner: "The Biography of a Poem" (on Paul Celan); "Translating Paul Celan's Du sei wie du"; "Paul Celan: The Strain of Jewishness"; "Repetition and Restitution: Translating Celan's Die Winzer"; "The Natural Prayer of the Soul"; and "Changing Faces in Max Beerbohm's Caricature". "Kafka and the Golem - Translating Paul Celan"; "The Island Worlds of Darwin and Melville" by H. Bruce Franklin; "Your Humble Servant: Strategic Humility in Bradstreet, Dickinson, and Jonson" by Kenneth Fields; issues from New Literary History, Religion and Literature, and Representations.

Contains publications by Terry Castle: "Eros and Liberty at the English Masquerade, 1710-90"; "Contagious Folly: An Adventure and its Skeptics"; "Sex Please--We're British"; "High Plains Drifter" (on Don Quixote). Publications by William A. Clebsch: "The Elizabethans on Luther"; "Southern Religion Resurrected"; "America's 'Mythique' as Redeemer Nation". Publications by W.B. Carnochan: "Darkly wise, rudely great"; "Where did great books come from anyway?"; "The Case of Julius Goebel". Other miscellaneous articles and publications from scholarly journals.

Contains "Timelessness, Foreknowledge, and Free Will" by Dennis Danielson; "Dante and the Verace Intendimento of the Nature Introduction"; "Alexandrian Methods of Interpretation and the Rabbis" by David Daube; "A Reading of the Changeling" and "Nebuchadnezzar's Children: Conventions of Madness in Middle English Literature" by Penelope B.R. Doob.

scopecontent.p: Contains publications by Robert W. Ackerman: "Sir Gawain and the Green Knight and its Intepreters"; "Sir Frederic Madden and the Study of Medieval Literature"; "Review: The Book of Kyng Arthur: The Unity of Malory's Morte Darther"; "Malory's Ironsyde". Publications by Alfred Appel, Jr.: "An Interview with Vladimir Nabokov"; "Vladimir Nabokov"; "Powerhouse's Blues"; "Lolita: The Springboard of Parody"; January 1967 issues of The New Republic; other publications on Beowulf and Dante.
Contains several publications by Herbert Lindenberger and others.

Contains "Poetry and Equity: Aristotle's Defense of Fiction" by Kathy Eden; "Agamemnon's Decision: Freedom and Folly in Aeschylus" by Mark W. Edwards; "A Muse of Fire: Henry V in the Light of Tamburlaine" by Robert Egan.

Contains "Epicurus and Voluptas in Late Antiquity: The Curious Testimony of Martianus Capella", "The Poet's Last Words: Text and Meaning at the End of the Parson's Prologue", Chaucer, the Merchant, and their Tale: Getting Beyond Old Controversies", and "Proserpina, Matelda, and the Pilgrim" by Emerson Brown, Jr.; "Love and Marriage in the Age of Chaucer" by Henry Ansgar Kelly; "Bede the Educator" by George Hardin Brown; chapter, "A New History of the Enlightenment?" from "The Profession of Eighteenth-Century Literature" by John Bender; chapter, "Prison Reform and the Sentence of Narration in The Vicar of Wakefield" from "The New Eighteenth Century" by John Bender; "The Day of the Tempest" and "Liberating the Sister Arts: The Revolution of Blake's Infant Sorrow" by John Bender; "Of Mice and Women: Thoughts on Chaucerian Allusion"; several publications from scholarly journals.

Contains chapter, "Areopagitica and Liberty" by Blair Hoxby from The Oxford Handbook of Milton; "Maiden in the Mor Lay and the medieval Magdalene Tradition" by Joseph Harris; "The Myden Makeles" by David G. Halliburton; publications from the Journal of English and Germanic Philology; Deutsches Dante-Jahrbuch, American Academy of Religion, A Journal of Medieval Studies, and Renaissance Quarterly.

Contains "Shakespeare's Sonnets: Age in Love and the Goring of Thoughts" by John Klause (from Studies in Philology, 1983); "Religious Language in Waiting for Godot" by V.A. Kolve (from The Centennial Review, 1967); "Political Theory and the Uses of the Self" by Nannerl O. Keohane (from Journal of Politics, 1975).
Contains October 1998 issue of "Speculum: A Journal of Medieval Studies".
Contains "The Blind" by Arturo Islas (from a Spring 1986 issue of "Zyzzyva").

Contains "Virginia Woolf and the Arts: Selected Papers from the Sixth Annual Conference on Virginia Woolf"; review by Terry Castle on "Casanova: The Man who Really Loved Women" by Lydia Flem and "History of my Life" by Giacomo Casanova (from The New Republic); "Either Or or And" by Nicholas Jenkins (from Yale Review); "The Monster in the Rainbows: Keats and the Science of Life" by Denise Gigante (from The Modern Language Association of America); "Textual Icons: Reading Early Modern Illustrations" by Stephen Orgel (from The Renaissance Computer); "Professions and Conversations on the Future of Literary and Cultural Studies" by Donald E. Hall; "Chicana Feminism and Postmodernist Theory" by Paula M.L. Moya (from Journal of Women in Culture and Society); "Literature and the Other Arts" by Herbert Lindenberger (from The Cambridge History of Literary Criticism).
Contains miscellaneous student files; graduate school application and student essays.

Contains 2000 issue of the Milton Quarterly; "Monuments and Ruins: Spenser and the Problem of the English Library" by Jennifer Summit; "Keeping up with the Past" by George Dekker; "Everybody Hates Kant: Blakean Formalism and the Symmetries of Laura Moriarty" by Robert Kaufman; "Tobacco and Boys: How Queer was Marlowe?" by Stephen Orgel; "Negatively Capable Dialectics: Keats, Vendler, Adorno, and the Theory of the Avant-Garde" by Robert Kaufman; "Milton's Aesthetics of Eating" by Denise Gigante; "Topography as Historiography: Petrarch, Chaucer, and the Making of Medieval Rome" by Jennifer Summit; "The Case for Comus" by Stephen Orgel; "The Favorite Child: David Copperfield and the Scriptural Issue of Child-Wives" by Robert M. Polhemus; "Latin Annotations in a Copy of Stowe's Chaucer and the Seventeenth-Century Reception of Troilus and Criseyde".

Contains several publications by Mary F. Wack: "New Medieval Medical Texts on amor hereos"; "The Liber de heros morbo of Johannes Afflacius and its Implications for Medieval Love Conventions"; "Imagination, Medicine, and Rhetoric in Andreas Capellanus' De Amore"; "Wolfram's Dawn Song, Sine Klawen"; "Lovesickness in Troilus"; miscellaneous publications by other scholars.
Contains 1997 issue of the Official Journal of the International Society for the History of Medicine.

Contains several publications by Wesley Trimpi: "Whose Worth's Unknown, although his Height be Taken"; "Reason and the Classical Premises of Literary Decorum"; "Konrad Gessner and Neoplatonic Poets"; "The Practice of Historical Interpretation and Nashe's Brightnesse Falls from the Ayre"; "Ben Jonson his Best Piece of Poetrie"; publication from a 1989 issue of The Cambridge History of Literary Criticism; "Sir Philip Sidney's An apology for poetry"; miscellaneous publications by other scholars.

Contains several publications by Jim Swan: "Giving New Depth to the Surface: Psychoanalysis, Literature, and Society"; application for faculty research fellowship; "Betwixt Two Labyrinths: Andrew Marvell's Rational Amphibian"; "Mater and Nannie: Freud's Two Mothers and the Discovery of the Oedipus Complex"; "History, Pastoral and Desire: Andrew Marvell's Mower Poems". Publications by G.F. Sensabaugh: "English Studies and the Crisis in Education"; "Tragic Effect in Webster's The White Devil"; two reviews from Renaissance Quarterly; miscellaneous publications from other scholars.

Contains several publications by Robert M. Polhemus: "Being in Love with Phineas Finn/Phineas Redux: Desire, Devotion, Consolation"; review on "Anthony Trollope and his Contemporaries: A Study in the Theory and Conventions of Mid-Victorian Fiction" by David Skilton and "South Africa" by Anthony Trollope; "Lewis Carroll and the Child in Victorian Fiction"; "John Millais's Children: Faith, Erotics, and The Woodman's Daughter"; publications by Nancy Huddleston Packer: "The Women Who Walk"; "Second Wind"; "Homecoming"; "Cousins"; "The Day the Tree Fell Down"; miscellaneous publications by other scholars.
Contains "What to make of a Dimished Thing"; "Crisis in the Humanities?"; "On Wanting to be a Comparatist".

Contains publications by Stephen Orgel: "The Example of Hercules"; "Shakespeare in stunning full colour"; offprint from "England and the Continental Renaissance"; "Insolent women and manlike apparel"; "Original copies".
Contains "The Quest of Seth, Solomon's Ship and the Grail" by Esther Casier Quinn.
Contains script of retreat talk from October 1990.

Contains publications by Thomas C. Moser: "Ford Maddox Hueffer and Under Western Eyes"; book reviews; "Joseph Conrad: Achievement and Decline". Publications by Anne K. Mellor: "Keats's Face of Moneta: Source and Meaning"; "Blake's Designs for The Book of Thel: An Affirmation of Innocence"; "The Human Form Divine and the Structure of Blake's Jerusalem"; book reviews.
Contains a collection of publications on Medieval and Renaissance literature and other topics.

did.unittitle: Publications by A.G. Rigg and F.C. Robinson

scopecontent.p: Contains publications by A.G. Rigg: "Hoccleve's Complaint and Isidore of Seville"; "The Letter C and the Date of Easter"; book review. Publications by F.C. Robinson: "Names in Old English Literature"; "The Complaynt Off Sanct Cipraine, The Grett Nigromancer: A Poem by Anthony Ascham"; "Review: Beowulf and the Fight at Finnsburgh: A Bibliography (D.K. Fry)"; "Beowulf's Retreat from Frisia: Some Textual Problems"; "Two Non-Cruces in Beowulf"; "Review: Old English Poetry: Fifteen Essays (R.P. Creed, Ed.)"; "Verb Tense in Blake's The Tyger"; "Lexicography and Literary Criticism: A Caveat". February 1970 and September 1971 copies of the Old English Newsletter; a June 1964 copy of The Oxford Magazine.

did.unittitle: Publications by Lucio Ruotolo and Lawrence V. Ryan

scopecontent.p: Contains publications by Lucio Ruotolo: "Keats and Kierksgaard: The Tragedy of Two Worlds"; "Mrs. Dalloway: The journey out of subjectivity"; "Three Prelude Events: The Growth of a Poet's Faith"; "Brighton Rock's Absurd Heroine"; "The Trinitarian Framework of Donne's Holy Sonnet XIV"; "Mrs. Dalloway: The Unguarded Moment". Publications by Lawrence V. Ryan: "Opening Address"; "Richard Hakluyt's Voyage Into Aristotle"; "The Shorter Latin Poem in Tudor England"; "Three Sonnets on Roman Life by Trilussa" (translations); "Conrad Celtis and the Mystique of Number"; "Erasmi Convivia: The Banquet Colloquies of Erasmus"; "The Canon's Yeoman's Desperate Confession"; "Stornei, Gru, Colombe: The Bird Images in Inferno V"; "Art and Artifice in Erasmus' Convivium Profanum".
Contains "Introduction"; "The Divided Self: Augustine's Confessions" (2 copies); "The Immutable Self: Thomas Hardy's The Mayor of Casterbridge"; and "Fantasy-Land"

Contains "The First-Person Epic: Dante's Divine Comedy"; "The Multiple Self: The Essays of Michael de Montaigne"; "Authorial Agency: Milton's Poetic Self-Construction; and "The Egotistical Sublime: Wordsworth's Resolution and Independence and Byron's Childe Harold's Pilgrimage"

Contains "Selves and Others: Twain's Innocents Abroad and James's The American Scene"; "The Fictional I: Graham Greene's Quiet American"; "Confession: Graham Greene's Quiet American"; and "Acknowledgements"
Contains "Wide Open Spaces"; "Departed Glories: American Writers in Italy"; "Native Sons: European Views of American Men"; and "Mother Land: American Writers in England"

did.unittitle: Textual Selves: Identity in Literature (1 of 2)

scopecontent.p: Contains Introduction and Chapters 1-3: "The Divided Self"; "The Multiple Self"; and "Poetic Agency"

did.unittitle: Textual Selves: Identity in Literature (2 of 2)

Contains Introduction and Chapters 1-4: "The Divided Self - Augustine and Dante"; "The Multiple Self - Montaigne"; "Poetic Agency - Milton"; and "The Egotistical Sublime - Wordsworth and Byron"

Contains Chapters 5-9: "Alien Encounters - Twain and James"; "The Immutable Self - Hardy"; "The Fictional 'I' - Greene"; "The Drama of Stasis - T.S. Eliot"; "The Hero with Two Faces - Brecht"; and Bibliography
Contains copies of poems in Williams’ anthology; Sonnet 116; "They Flee from Me" by Sir Thomas Wyatt; "Nature, that Washed her Hands in Milk" by Sir Walter Raleigh.

Contains hand-written notes; partially complete draft on America as the New World; 1964 article from The Illustrated London News, "Pamela. The Earliest English Novel"; 2007 article from TIME, "Inventing America: The 400th Anniversary of Jamestown".

Contains pressboard binder with two plays inside: "Miss Cramm" and "Odysseus and the Cyclops"; appendices contain music notes, including fragments of ancient Greek music arranged for recorder by Donald C. Johns.
Contains excerpts from "The Unfortunate Traveller" by Thomas Nashe.
Contains student essay, "Sargent's Italy" from MLA 93, "Italy in the Anglo-American Imagination".
Contains printouts of excerpts from "A Month by the Lake" by H.E. Bates; "Pictures of Fidelman" by Bernard Malamud; "Cuttlefish Bones" by Eugenio Montale; and "Twilight in Italy" by D.H. Lawrence.

Contains printouts from "The Carburetor"; "Made in USSR"; "The Story of a Panic"; "Don Juan" by Lord Byron; poems by G.K. Chesterton; "The Three Fat Women of Antibes"; "Chagrin in Three Parts"; "America the Menace"; "Extra Virgin" by Annie Hawes; "Mario and the Magician" by Thomas Mann; the ninth day/third story from "The Decameron" by Giovanni Boccaccio; and "The Innocents Abroad" by Mark Twain. Also contains hand-written notes.
Contains printouts from "Letters from my Windmill"; "Roman Fever" by Edith Wharton; "The Leopard" by Giuseppe di Lampedusa; and poems by Lord Byron.

Contains printouts of excerpts from "Voices of Gallipoli" by Maurice Shadbolt; "The Mill on the Po" by Riccardo Bacchelli; "Rappaccini's Daughter" by Nathaniel Hawthorne; "Ferrara and my Last Duchess" by Louis S. Friedland; "Teem - A Treasure-Hunter" by Rudyard Kipling; "On the Extinction of the Venetian Republic" by William Wordsworth; poems by Lord Byron; and "Ithaka" by Constantine Cavafy. Also contains hand-written notes.

Contains printouts from "Ithaka" by Constantine Cavafy; "Italian Neighbors" by Tim Parks; "The Wilder Shores of Love" by Aimee Dubucq de Rivery; "Teem - A Treasure Hunter"; "The Fall of the Byzantine Empire"; "Where Angels Fear to Tread" by E.M. Forster; a preface by Iris Origo; "The Story of San Michele"; "Hero and Leander" by Christopher Marlowe; poems by W.B. Yeats; "Etruscan Places" by D.H. Lawrence; "Sea and Sardinia" by D.H. Lawrence; "Roman Fever" by Edith Wharton; "Albergo Empedocle" by E.M. Forster; "The Leopard" by Giuseppe di Lampedusa; and "The Story of a Panic".

physdesc.extent: Contains hand-written notes on Horace; student work, "Summary of Pope's 'An Essay on Criticism'"; excerpt from "The Odes of Horace".
Contains hand-written notes on Marx; Marx's poetry; student essays; supplemental images.
Contains excerpt, "Why Write?" by Jean-Paul Sartre; "Wording and Rewording" by John Carey; hand-written notes; student essays; miscellaneous files on reader interpretation.
Contains hand-written notes on Thomas Love Peacock; student summary of the foreword to "In Defense of Reason" by Yvor Winters; excerpt, "The Four Ages of Poetry".
Empty file.
Contains script from lecture on Plato; student work; hand-written notes; passage from "Inferno".
Contains hand-written notes; "Reader-Response Criticism: From Formalism to Post-Structuralism"; supplements to the work of Aquinas and Boccaccio; student essay on reader interpretation.

Contains hand-written notes and introduction to a script from a lecture on Aristotle; supplemental passage from "Saint Augustine Confessions"; article on Ivor Armstrong Richards; student responses to "Principles of Literary Criticism".
Contains "The Personal Heresy: A Controversy" essays by C.S. Lewis and E.M.W. Tillyard; student essays; excerpts from "What is an Author?" by Michael Foucault.
Empty file.
Contains notes and lecture scripts related to Samuel Johnson; student essays; course materials; article, "Educating for Survival: A Call for a Core Curriculum" by Ernest L. Boyer and Martin Kaplan.
Contains hand-written notes on Philip Sidney and student essays.
Contains student essays; article, "Freud's Theory of Dream Interpretation"; article, "Family Systems Psychotherapy, Literary Character, and Literature: An Introduction" by John V. Knapp.
Contains hand-written notes on Matthew Arnold; poems, "The Buried Life", "Growing Old", and "The Last Word"; student work.
Contains hand-written notes on T.S. Eliot; Eliot poems; "Originality is the hallmark of great literature" and student responses; student essays; supplemental passages.

Contains hand-written notes on Carl G. Jung; "Contributions to Analytical Psychology: On the Relation of Analytical Psychology to Poetic Art"; 1982 issue from The Review of English Studies; student essays.
Contains hand-written notes on feminism and feminist criticism; Anne Howard poems; student responses to "Literary experience is always gendered"; student essays.
Contains hand-written notes on Freud; excerpt, "Creative Writers and Day-Dreaming" by Sigmund Freud; San Francisco Chronicle article, "Is it the Muse or mental illness?"; student essay.
Contains guide on tools for locating information and resources related to English literature; hand-written notes.
Contains materials from English 100 (Renaissance Literature); preliminary class list, student essays, and copies of poems ("Astrophel and Stella", "Desire", and "Splendidis Longum Valedico Nugis").
Contains materials from honors seminars; reserve lists, syllabus, end quarter reports, and student essay.
Contains course materials from English 162 (Literary Criticism). Course adoption information, lecture scripts, class roster, hand-outs, notes, and final exam.

did.unittitle: The Poetry of John Milton – Student Records and Syllabi

physdesc.extent: Contains course grades and copies of syllabus from "The Poetry of John Milton" seminar.
Contains materials from several English courses; midterm and final examinations; syllabi; lecture scripts; reference sheet on technical terms in literature; preliminary class lists.
Contains course materials from English 9/109, "Chaucer, Shakespeare, Milton and their Contemporaries".
Contains excerpt from "America the Menace" by Georges Duhamel; excerpt from "Love in America" by Raoul de Roussy de Sales; hand-written notes on Duhamel.
Contains course materials from English 100J, "The Reciprocal Vision"; syllabi; hand-written notes; quizzes; research reports; newspaper clippings; student grades.
Foreword and excerpt from "Image of America" by Raymond Bruckberger; excerpt from "The American Challenge"; hand-written notes; newspaper clippings.

Contains materials related to course, "Living in the Past: Italy in the Anglo-American Imagination"; syllabi; maps of Italy; chronology outlines; clipping of San Francisco Chronicle article, "Love, literature, leisure: Trove of Italy guidebooks".
Contains script from lecture on "Candide" by Voltaire and supplemental music lyrics; administrative files from various classes; class syllabi.

scopecontent.p: Contains student essays; "Mark Twain and the Florentine Renaissance Humanists"; "Self and Belonging in the Anglo-American Imagination from MLA 93.

accessrestrict.p: Student and personnel records restricted 75 years from date of creation.

did.unittitle: Humanities and Sciences Associate Dean Letters (1 of 2)
Humanities and Sciences Associate Dean Letters (2 of 2)

scopecontent.p: Contains a copy of the Report of the Commission on Undergraduate Education (1994); undergraduate and graduate student survey results from the English Department (1996-1997); copy of a report from a department meeting (May 1997, "Rethinking Undergraduate Studies in English"); personal e-mails; handwritten notes.

physdesc.extent: Contains professional correspondence, meeting notes, and hand-written notes from business related to the Appointments and Promotions (A&P) Committee. Opinions section from an October 27, 1975 copy of The Stanford Daily.

scopecontent.p: Contains report on curriculum for 1998-99; copy of template letter to assistant professors on course scheduling; hand-written notes.
Contains materials related to qualifying examinations.
Contains professional correspondence, newspaper articles, and logistical materials related to the Western Culture Program.
Contains a collection of news articles and correspondence related to the Western Culture Program.
Contains student files from English 162: Critical Methods; course syllabus from Literary Criticism and Literary Texts: The Anglo-American Tradition; student essays.
Contains Part 1 of "Itinerary" by Fynes Moryson.
Contains mementos from travel to England and Italy; pamphlets, postcards, photographs, and notes.
Contains books; "Historical Atlas of the World"; "The Marble Pavement of the Cathedral of Siena"; "Literary Cities of Italy".
Contains newspaper articles related to academic tenure.

Contains articles from The Stanford Daily and the San Francisco Chronicle related to Dean Lucille A. Allen’s terminal leave of absence and Associate Professor H. Bruce Franklin’s dismissal from the English Department; professional correspondence.

Contains news articles related to instruction in liberal education and the humanities; defense of the humanities from Stanford professors in response to Stanley Fish; letter to President Donald Kennedy and Provost James Rosse from the Area One Program Committee (The Program in Cultures, Ideas, and Values) regarding hiring of faculty.

Contains newspaper articles; hand-written notes; correspondence; questions for Dean Evans submitted by members of the Humanities 353 colloquium (1978); draft of "The Unfinished Renaissance of the Humanities" by Professor William Clebsch (1978); materials from the Commission on the Humanities (1979).

physdesc.extent: Contains article from The New Yorker, "Return to Paradise: The enduring relevance of John Milton"; musical notes from "The Masque of Comus", composed by Henry Lawes.
Contains draft, "Poetic Agency: The Poems of Mr. John Milton".

Contains outline, script, and notes on "Lycidas" by John Milton; outline, "The Conventions of Pastoral Elegy"; "Lycidas" resources; copies of "From Obsequies to the Memorie of Mr. Edward King--Opening Poem by Henry King"; clipping, "The Reason of Church Government"; "Lycidas - A Eulogistic Review" by J.M. Evans; "Outline: Virgil's Eclogue X and the Pastoral Elegy"; excerpt from Theocritus.
Contains writings on John Milton's poems.
